column5: yep...already in shaving kit...just have to remember to bring that..
One of my favorite shopping sprees. I'm like a kid in a candy store.
Don't get them mixed up.
money!
Bring more than one set of spreaders. As we speak there is a nice 6 lb pike swimming in Jan lake with a set in his jaw.

Believe it or not I once threw in a large piece of plexiglass (20"x30") on he way up a deer hit us and knocked out the drivers window.....cut plexiglass and duct tape and we wee back on the road in an hour.

Get yourself a big first aid kit and learn how to use it. Also, buy a Knipex mini bolt cutter. We have removed plenty of big ole hooks from people;s flesh with it. Even performed minor surgery on a golden retriever that decided to retrieve a musky lure.

For the dry hands use hand cream for fishy hands try cornhuskers lotion good for chapped, cracked hands and fingers. I bring a small container of Aloe Vera thaT can be used for alot of things from sketter, bites, sunburn and small cuts and cracked skin. Jimmie
All these suggestions are good!!! 'cept the Jim Beam one perhaps in order to not mix it up with deet leave Jim at home!!! LOL Everyone be safe and have fun on the water!! Jimmie.
Super-Glue.Great for cuts, can fix some fishing items in a pinch. I have yet to not use it on any fishing trip.
Spare rod tips / guides.

Been there - my buddy could not handle the booze after we were done fishing and he went "bonk" straight down to the floor. Had about a 2" cut wide open to the skull right above his brow. The rest of us all had too much to safely drive anywhere, so we had no choice but to clean him up ourselves. A little super glue, and some butterflies and he was good to go the rest of the week.

I eat a very heart healthy diet at home ,but my fishing trip is a different matter. We are taking in 2 loaves of cinnamon -raisin bread with us . Makes the best french toast you ever ate . Try it . Would not leave home without it .
Big bottle of Jim Beam in case you develop a cough....Deet!!!!
A flashlight or similar. It's very dark at night.
Wet wipes...
Smart!
Natalie Gulbis
For my August trip to NW Ontario it's my wife of 55 years.

A 12" wire is always in my tackle bag for cleaning sand from the pee hole on my outboard motor. Try not to have a sharp end or it might stick into the side of the hose you're clearing. You can probably guess how I know this. I've put it to use on other's motors out on the lake.Beats pulling in an overheated motor.
bug spray bug spray

What I have used is a piece of weedeater nylon line. Probably the same precaution applies, make sure so real sharp ends on it. Actually, 30 years ago, I used the straw out of a juice box to blow and flush out out the pee hole line on a camp motor we plugged up. Saved our bacon, as we were on a fly-in with no one else for miles.
We are now spoiled and bring along our vacuum sealer for transporting the fish back home. It isn't a must but it sure is nice to be able to package up the fish like we do at home. TonyO
a sense of humor! ...and beer!

A boat sponge for keeping boat clean and for wiping off wet seats in the mornings. Also a can of Raid to be left in the outhouse all week. Spray some in hole prior to sitting ,as I hate bites on the bottom .

Call your auto insurance agency and ask them to issue you a Proof of Insurance card for Canada/Ontario. If you're stopped or in any type of accident you'll be asked for Proof of your Auto Liability Insurance for the vehicle you are operating. Be sure to have this card, and you'll save yourself a headache. Rich B
100' of lightweight yellow nylon rope for the anchor. Spare pair of sunglasses extra zip lock bags stringer
portable downrigger....everyday after lunch we spend a couple hrs chasing lakers.
LOL, for all those that said "Beer", we have over 300 products at our Beer stores so just bring the "big wad of sweaty money". Cheers!
Beer of course
a few things that come to mind that people have not already mentioned are:thermacellfirst aid kitgps
The keys to the cabinBreakfast sausage and deli meat from Zup's Grocery in Cook, MN
Something soft to set on for the camp boats.
Mack's Ear Plugs. not only do they block out the snoring, they keep the wind from driving you insane on those really windy days. Have even used 'em to caulk a cracked window on a chilly night.KT
mosquito coils.various tools for on-the-water engine repair...got lucky last year, able to MacGyver my way back to camp when the bendicks went haywire...
After Bite
extra batteriesGallon zip lockstoothbrushflashlighthat
Not essential but definitely missed last year: jig eye buster (it was in my ice fishing box)
mosquito coils." Bingo...they are a must bring..
For those that fish out of camp boats a 12v bilge pump is handy on those rainy weeks!
The best of friends, family and booze!!! If you have those 3 things you can manage with whatever else you forgot!!!
Batter!Batter!!Batter!!!Shawiiiiiing Batter!!!! ............. for frying up some lunch
Nippers or small scissors for cutting braid.
I would have to go with BEER as well.
Beer, ice, rope, and a good first aid kit
Neosporin ointment for cuts.
tylenol, advil etc etc Having a bad headache while on a fishing trip can be terrible! I get migraines sometimes that can put me in bed for a day if I don't have a decent amount of pain killers.
bathroom spray
LOL. Yep, don't leave home without it. I also take wet wipes...stops the brown racing stripe in your underwear.
Don't forget the Corn Huskers lotion!!
Chapstick and polarized sunglasses
Boat Keys
Small boltcutters. Knipex is good.
Besides the pliers, bring a mouth opener (spring device for keeping pike's mouth open while you are trying to retrieve your vanished lure). Bill Krejca
If you are going to an outpost or camping: duct tape.
Condoms
Definitely boat keys.
Take two in case you forget to take it out of the pike before you throw her back!
You need that to come back home!

What is an item that isn't obvious, that people forget to bring to Canada? I just recently starting bringing a coleman coffee thermos. The coffee stays hot for hours. A cup or two of coffee is nice in the late evening in the boat or on the boat ride home.Another item is a headlamp.
Sunblock.

Common sense? I think people sometimes also don't respect the fact that you are more then 10 minutes away from a doctor if needed. They also need to remember that just because it's your vacation, it's someone else's resort and country. Treat your hosts and their facilities with respect and care.
"a big wad of sweaty money"Melvin Udall "As Good as it Gets"

Well, it's obvious, but I probably give away 15 tooth brushes per summer. In my opinion, the #1 most important thing is GOOD rain gear. I can use a junky pole, I can even fish out of a canoe if I have to. But, staying dry is key.
Extra long needle nose pliers - at least 2.
My hands dry out something fierce!
BEER!!!!!! Rain gear is pretty important too...
TP.
Passport!
